The Basic Law established an executive-run government in Hong Kong, led by the Chief Executive, who is selected by an Election Committee. Election reforms in 2010 expanded the Committee and increased the nomination threshold. The date for the selection of Hong Kong's fourth Chief Executive was set for March 25, 2012. The selection of Hong Kong's fourth Chief Executive was set for March 25, 2012, with three candidates submitting nomination papers. Henry Tang Ying-yen, CY Leung, and Albert Ho Chun-yan were the main contenders, with Tang facing challenges before the selection day. Henry Tang faced numerous challenges before the selection day for Hong Kong's Chief Executive, including admitting to an affair, questions about his academic credentials, and illegal construction work on his house. His dishonesty and attempts to shift blame eroded his public image, leading to a sharp shift in support to CY Leung. After a sharp shift in public support from Henry Tang to CY Leung, Leung won the election for Hong Kong's Chief Executive in March 2012. Rumors circulated that the Chinese government switched its support to Leung. Leung won with 689 votes, while Tang finished second with 285 votes.
